item.title: UK Joins US, France in Backing Morocco Plan for West Sahara
item.description: The UK backed Morocco’s plan to administer the disputed territory of Western Sahara, in a historic shift mirroring moves by France and the US.
item.dc:creator: Souhail Karam

media:content.media:description: Camels roam next to wind turbines that will supply power to a desalination plant under construction in Dakhla in the disputed Western Sahara on May 26, 2025.

item.title: At Least 21 Palestinians Killed Heading to Gaza Aid Hub, Hospital Says
item.description: RAFAH, Gaza Strip (AP) — At least 31 people were killed and over 170 were wounded on Sunday while on their way to receive food in the Gaza Strip, according to health officials and multiple witnesses. The witnesses said Israeli forces fired on crowds around a kilometer (1,000 yards) from a new aid site run by an Israeli-backed foundation.

media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinians ferry bags of food aid after storming a World Food Programme warehouse in Deir el-Balah in the central Gaza Strip on May 28 Photo by Eyad BABA/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: EYAD BABA/AFP

item.title: Bessent Says US Will Never Default as Congress Faces Endgame
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the US “is never going to default” as the deadline for increasing the federal debt ceiling gets closer.
item.dc:creator: Tony Czuczka

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a Bloomberg Television interview in New York, US, on Friday, May 23, 2025. Bessent said that US regulators this summer may ease a rule that’s served as a constraint on banks’ trading in the $29 trillion Treasuries market. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Musk Denies Ketamine Use Following New York Times Report
item.description: Billionaire Elon Musk said that he is not using the drug ketamine, disputing a report by the New York Times that alleged extensive use of that and other drugs.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Chaves

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk during a news conference in the Oval Office of the White House on May 30. Photographer: Francis Chung/Politico

item.title: Germany Plans Corporate Tax Breaks to Spur Investment, DPA Says
item.description: German Finance Minister Lars Klingbeil is planning a number of tax breaks for companies aimed at spurring investment and lifting the economy out of its long bout of stagnation, according to Deutsche Presse-Agentur.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: A Volkswagen ID.5 electric car displayed in the showroom at the Volkswagen AG factory in Dresden, Germany, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. Volkswagen and other EV makers appear to be benefiting from consumers’ aversion to Tesla after Elon Musk became more involved in US President Donald Trump’s administration and supported far-right political movements in Europe, such as Germany’s AfD party.

item.title: UK Shifts War Footing To ‘Always-On’ Munitions Production
item.description: The UK will create an “always on” munitions production capacity to allow it to scale-up its defense industry when needed, as it increasingly shifts to a war footing with Russia’s assault on Ukraine showing little sign of ending.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Amedeo Goria

media:content.media:description: UK soldiers maneuver an anti-aircraft gun during the 'Allied Spirit25' US military and NATO training exercise in Hohenfels, Germany, on March 12.

item.title: Hegseth Reassures Asia Allies Unsettled by Trump: Balance of Power
item.description: Welcome to a special edition of Balance of Power, focusing on the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore. Each weekday we bring you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans, Alberto Nardelli, Josh Xiao, Alastair Gale

media:content.media:description: Pete Hegseth, US secretary of defense, gives a thumbs up during the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore, on Saturday, May 31, 2025. The conference runs through June 1. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

item.title: Hegseth Wins Praise But Asia Still Has Strong Doubts About Trump
item.description: After US military allies in Europe were torched by Vice President JD Vance in March over military spending, free speech and the war in Ukraine, America’s partners in Asia warily awaited Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s arrival at a security conference in Singapore.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Philip Heijmans, Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Pete Hegseth, US secretary of defense, during the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore.

item.title: Hungary’s Top Court Strikes Down Police Ban on LGBTQ Gathering
item.description: Hungary’s top court struck down a police ban of a pro-LGBTQ gathering in Budapest, in a test of Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s escalating culture war before elections next year.
item.dc:creator: Zoltan Simon

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators march during the annual Pride parade in Budapest, Hungary, on Saturday, July 24, 2021. Brussels is threatening action over an LGBTQ law that could involve cutting funds to Budapest; Prime Minister Viktor Orban has proposed to put what he calls the protection of children against homosexual content to a referendum.

item.title: Bangladesh Charges Ex-PM Hasina With Crimes Against Humanity
item.description: Bangladeshi prosecutors officially charged former prime minister Sheikh Hasina and two senior officials with crimes against humanity for their alleged roles in violent crackdowns during the 2024 student-led uprising.
item.dc:creator: Arun Devnath

media:content.media:description: Sheikh Hasina, Bangladesh's prime minister, speaks during the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) in New York, US, on Friday, Sept. 22, 2023. Global leaders descend upon midtown Manhattan this week for speeches, meetings and receptions, an annual migration to the United Nations meant to tackle the world's biggest problems.

item.title: Iran Says It’s Not After Nuclear Bombs as It Rejects IAEA Report
item.description: Iran criticized a new report by the UN nuclear watchdog accusing it of nuclear violations, claiming the agency is motivated by politics and reiterating it isn’t seeking atomic weapons.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: A picture taken on November 10, 2019, shows an Iranian flag in Iran's Bushehr nuclear power plant, during an official ceremony to kick-start works on a second reactor at the facility. - Bushehr is Iran's only nuclear power station and is currently running on imported fuel from Russia that is closely monitored by the UN's International Atomic Energy Agency. (Photo by ATTA KENARE / AFP) (Photo by ATTA KENARE/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: Atta Kenare/AFP

item.title: Philippine Defense Chief Rips China in Testy In-Person Exchange
item.description: Philippine Defense Secretary Gilberto Teodoro engaged in a testy back-and-forth with Chinese officials at a Singapore security forum on Sunday, accusing leaders in Beijing of grabbing territory in disputed waters and repressing their own people.
item.dc:creator: Cliff Harvey Venzon, Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Gilberto Teodoro Jr. on June 1. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

item.title: Bangladesh Islamist Party Set For Comeback as Court Removes Ban
item.description: Bangladesh’s top court has reinstated the registration of Jamaat-e-Islami, paving the way for the country’s largest Islamist party to participate in the next election.
item.dc:creator: Arun Devnath

media:content.media:description: Bangladesh's Jamaat-e-Islami leader A.T.M. Azharul Islam (C) gestures after he was released from prison in Dhaka on May 28, 2025. Bangladesh's top court on May 27, 2025, overturned a conviction against a key leader of the country's main Islamist party, who had been on death row since being sentenced under the regime ousted last year. A.T.M. Azharul Islam, from the Jamaat-e-Islami party, and who has been in custody since 2012, was acquitted of crimes against humanity by the Supreme Court, which ordered his release. (Photo by MUNIR UZ ZAMAN / AFP) (Photo by MUNIR UZ ZAMAN/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: China Blasts Hegseth as Defense Minister Avoids Singapore Forum
item.description: China lodged a protest over Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s speech at a defense forum in Singapore on Saturday, even as Beijing chose not to send its top military diplomat to the annual event.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Ying Tian

media:content.media:description: Pete Hegseth on May 31. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

item.title: Germany Vows to Maintain Role in Asia Security Despite US Calls
item.description: Germany’s top military officer said the country would continue to play a role in Asia-Pacific security, even as the US urges European nations to focus more on the threat from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: Carsten Breuer Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Five Key Takeaways From Asia Defense Forum in Singapore: TOPLive
item.description: Here are key takeaways from the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue security forum in Singapore:
item.dc:creator: Jasmine Ng

media:content.media:description: Pete Hegseth on May 30. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

item.title: Polish Election Pits Former Boxer Against Warsaw Mayor: What to Watch
item.description: Poles elect their president on Sunday in the biggest test yet of whether Prime Minister Donald Tusk’s pro-European agenda is going to prevail against the surge of the country’s nationalist forces.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Ojewska

media:content.media:description: Voters mark their ballots in a polling station in Warsaw, Poland, on Sunday, June 1, 2025. Poles elect their president on Sunday in the biggest test yet of whether Prime Minister Donald Tusk’s pro-European agenda is going to prevail against the surge of the country’s nationalist forces.

item.title: British Man Charged in US With Spying for China
item.description: A British man has been charged in the US with spying for China, officials in the US confirmed.

item.title: Traders’ Guide to Navigating South Korea’s Presidential Vote
item.description: South Korea’s presidential vote is putting the spotlight on energy, brokerage and domestic-focused shares in the country’s outperforming $1.8 trillion equity market.
item.dc:creator: Youkyung Lee, Jaehyun Eom

media:content.media:description: Voters prepare to cast their ballots during the early voting period at a polling station inside Incheon International Airport in Incheon, South Korea, on Thursday, May 29, 2025. The election of a new South Korea president is seen vital to restoring confidence in the nation’s government and its economy after six months of political instability, sparked by Yoon’s abrupt declaration of martial law.

item.title: Korea’s Presidential Front-Runner Backs Nuclear Power — for Now
item.description: South Korea’s presidential front-runner Lee Jae-myung has pledged to keep nuclear power “for the time being,” but plans a long-term shift to renewables if elected June 3 — a stance that could undermine the nation’s atomic energy expansion plans at home and abroad.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung, presidential candidate for the Democratic Party, speaks to members of the media outside a polling station during the early voting period in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, May 29, 2025. The election of a new South Korea president is seen vital to restoring confidence in the nation’s government and its economy after six months of political instability, sparked by Yoon’s abrupt declaration of martial law. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: White House Planning to Replace NASA Administrator Nominee
item.description: The White House said on Saturday it would name a new nominee for NASA administrator, just days before billionaire Jared Isaacman, the current pick, was to face his planned Senate confirmation vote.
item.dc:creator: Loren Grush, Sana Pashankar

media:content.media:description: Jared Isaacman, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) nominee for US President Donald Trump, during a Senate Commerce, Science, and Transportation Committee confirmation hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. President Donald Trump's nominee to run NASA will tell US senators the agency's priority will be to send US astronauts to Mars, while promoting a thriving space economy in orbit.

item.title: US Envoy Calls Hamas Answer to Truce Proposal ‘Unacceptable’
item.description: Hamas said it submitted a response to the US proposal for a truce in Gaza, but Trump administration envoy Steve Witkoff quickly dismissed it as “totally unacceptable.”
item.dc:creator: Fadwa Hodali, Sara Gharaibeh

media:content.media:description: Hamas fighters secure an area before handing over three Israeli hostages to a Red Cross team in Deir el-Balah, Gaza, on Feb. 8. Photographer: Eyad Baba/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Iran Says Oman Presented a US Proposal Amid Nuclear Talks
item.description: Iran said on Saturday that Oman’s Foreign Minister Badr Albusaidi presented a US proposal to the country during a visit to the Iranian capital.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi, left, meets with Omani Foreign Minister Badr bin Hamad al-Busaidi as part of the fifth round of nuclear talks between Iran and the United States in Rome, Italy, in this handout photo released by the Iranian Foreign Ministry on May 23, 2025.

item.title: Trump Tariffs Face Threat at Supreme Court — Over Rulings That Blocked Biden
item.description: A legal argument that the US Supreme Court used to foil Joe Biden on climate change and student debt now looms as a threat to President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump holds a reciprocal tariffs poster in the Rose Garden of the White House in Washington on April 2. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: Germany’s Merz Secures Long-Awaited Trump Meeting on June 5
item.description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz will travel to Washington for his inaugural meeting with US President Donald Trump next week, almost a month after starting his term leading Europe’s largest economy.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz

item.title: Elon Musk’s Court Fights to Outlast His Time at White House
item.description: As Elon Musk leaves his formal US government position, dozens of legal challenges over the billionaire’s powerful role in the Trump administration and the work of the Department of Government Efficiency will press ahead.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, and Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., during a news conference in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce.

item.title: Trump’s Promises of Easy Wins Meet Reality During a Rocky Week
item.description: President Donald Trump returned to office promising to easily fix generationally intractable problems, from quickly brokering peace in Ukraine and the Middle East to overhauling the federal government and rewriting the global trade order.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a news conference with Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce.

item.title: Iran’s Near Bomb-Grade Uranium Stockpile Grows by a Record
item.description: Iran manufactured a record volume of uranium enriched just below the levels needed for nuclear weapons, complicating efforts to negotiate a peaceful resolution to international concerns over the Islamic Republic’s atomic ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: An Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) speed boat is sailing along the Persian Gulf during the IRGC marine parade, which is commemorating the Persian Gulf National Day, near the Bushehr nuclear power plant in the seaport city of Bushehr, Bushehr province, in the south of Iran, on April 29, 2024. The Persian Gulf National Day, celebrated on the 10th of Ordibehesht in the Iranian calendar, usually falls in late April or early May and commemorates the expulsion of the Portuguese from the Strait of Hormuz and the Persian Gulf in 1622 by the Safavid forces led by Imam Quli Khan under the command of Shah Abbas I. (Photo by Morteza Nikoubazl/NurPhoto via Getty Images)

item.title: Sweden on Track Toward 5% NATO Target, Defense Minister Says
item.description: Sweden is on track to increase military spending in line with goals that are expected to be agreed at NATO’s upcoming summit in the Hague, the Nordic country’s defense minister said.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Duxbury

media:content.media:description: KIVILOMPOLO, FINLAND - MARCH 09: Swedish soldiers take part in an exchange of fire with "enemy troops" using blan rounds during a training exercise, visible to the media, on the Finland/Norway border during the Nordic Response military exercise on March 09, 2024 in Kivilompolo, Finland. The exercise, which primarily takes place across Scandinavia from March 3-14, features 20,000 troops from 13 allied countries. Following the recent NATO expansion.

item.title: Russian Assets Deserve Closer Look, German Official Tells FAS
item.description: The European Union should revisit the question of how hundreds of billions of euros in frozen Russian assets can be used to finance Ukraine, a top German official said.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: The golden domes of the Kremlin's churches and cathedrals sit in Moscow, Russia, on Sunday, May 27, 2018. President Vladimir Putin told executives from foreign companies that Russia won’t punish its international partners for compliance with anti-Russian sanctions, spokesman Dmitry Peskov said by phone. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg
